article: After my 26 second-graders finished reciting the text, they settled back in their seats. But Duane was still  _  there. Duane was a bright and lovable student,  _  his mother, a single parent, had many problems such as drinking.  _  that he might have had a bad night, I walked over to him to see what was wrong. As he looked up, I could see the  _  in his dark eyes. "Mrs. Brown, aren't you going to open my present for you?" he asked  _  . "I put it on your desk." Getting back his gift from my desk, he handed it to me. I noticed my gift  _  to be a matchbox. Duane told me that this was really a jewelry box  rather than  a matchbox. As I opened it, the  _  of two beer caps surprised me. Duane  _  me that they were two earrings. He had noticed that I  _  wore earrings and wanted me to have some pretty ones. I was  _  by Duane's creativity and thoughtfulness.  _  birth, one of my ears was slightly deformed . Fearing that wearing earrings might  draw attention  to the ear, I avoided wearing them. But how could I  _  to wear these precious earrings given by this  _  child? As I placed the earrings on my ears, my  _  clapped , and Duane stood proudly beside me. Since then, the matchbox remained on my desk. It  _  me of Duane's act of kindness and of the lessons he taught me. Although his  _  at home was bad, Duane continued to see the good in life. Although poor, he still wanted to  _  . Whenever I see Duane's gift on my desk, I feel encouraged. If I am having  _  reaching a student, I'll try to be like Duane and give that student a piece of my heart.
